ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Convex analysis, gradient descent, subgradient methods, proximal methods, Lagrangian duality and KKT conditions, Newton's method, interior-point methods, distributed optimization and ADMM, conic and semidefinite programming, stochastic gradient descent
I learned foundational topics in convex optimization.
A very theoretical treatment to optimization. Convex analysis, subdifferential, KKT, gradient descent, subgradient descent, distributed algorithm, SDP (semidefinite programing).

This course started out with some basic tools necessary to tackle optimization problems: convexity, separating and supporting hyperplane theorems, optimality conditions for convex problems, gradient descent and corresponding convergence rates, subdifferentiability, KKT conditions, weak and strong duality, etc. 

In the last portion of the course, Sekhar gave us an introduction to some very exciting subfields within optimization: distributed methods, interior point methods (these are very interesting), generalized inequalities and generalized KKT conditions, stochastic gradient descent (do you actually know how Adam works?), etc.

This course is very useful to learn about the core topics in convex optimization, ranging from basic convex analysis and gradient descent to Newton method and interior point methods. The main insight I gained in this class is to always reason about duality when we deal with a constrained (convex) optimization problem, going through the KKT conditions.
The landscape of optimization, very thorough.
Optimization
I learned many optimization techniques including GD, SGD, ADMM, Newton's method, and so on.
Convex optimization, duality, KKT conditions, various forms of gradient descent, interior point methods
The topics were very interesting, I learned a lot
Advanced optimization techniques
Optimization concepts and techniques
Multiple techniques for optimization.
Its great!

Knowledge about foundations of convex optimization, gradient descent and different variations on gradient descent algorithms and their theoretical guarantees. KKT conditions and constrained optimization. Some high level recognition of more niche optimization topics.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: interesting and useful material, lectures easy to follow ======== Weaknesses: some homework problems involved a lot of semi-obscure linear algebra

I think the course is very well-organized, accessible, and enjoyable to attend. The workload was a bit high, but I believe assignments are necessary to learn the material for the course. One suggestion is to possibly have longer, bi-weekly problems sets rather than weekly to be more flexible for students to plan around.

Strengths: The material was incredibly interesting and I often left lectures completely mind blown about what I had just learned (yes, the material is really that cool). Sekhar is also the best professor to be teaching the course. He simply knows so much about the field of optimization and also cares so much about the success of his students.

Weaknesses: The only improvement I could think of is with regard to the homework assignments. Sometimes I felt that the problems were meaningless for my understanding of the course material. I do think, though, that this is because the course was being taught for the first time this semester.

Gives a great survey for different optimization methods and the mathematical principles behind them. However, for someone with limited exposure to this field, the content is very heavy and intense, and it is easy to leave a class without an in-depth understanding of the topics. 

Instead of giving weekly problem sets which only includes mathematical derivation, maybe give bi-weekly problem sets which are longer but include both derivation and implementation of the algorithms to facilitate better understanding of the topics covered.

The main strength of this course is that it covers a lot of fundamental topics in convex optimization with mathematical rigor. Moreover, Sekhar is a great teacher and he is always available for clarifications. The problem sets are also often related to the content of the lectures, and I found most of them useful.
The course gives intuition about many complicated optimization algorithms.

I really enjoyed this class. Sekhar is an amazing professor and his lectures are the highlight of the course. We cover highly technical problems but he makes sure to motivate each concept and also harkens back to big picture/high level overviews of the class so that we dont get lost in the technicality of the proofs. One thing I would say is that perhaps the workload for psets in the latter half of the semester could be a little less so that we have more time to focus on the final project.
The assignments were great practice, lectures well taught and organized
strengths are the lecutres. would be nice if recorded
It is well organized and well taught
The course is extremely good as it is.
No weakness

Strengths: Sekhar is very organized, kind, and approachable as a professor. He seems passionate about the subject and find the most optimal ways to transmit the information to us. There isn't stress of midterms of finals, which is nice given how technical some of the subject matter can be - it gives you more time to explore and work through the material at your own pace.

Weaknesses: While Sekhar seemed very well prepared for the lectures and there was space for students to ask questions, a lot of the content felt impermeable in lectures. Since we often delved straight into technical concepts / long proofs, it felt easy to lose track of what we were doing and the goal for the proofs. Maybe this is the nature of the subject or my own personal block about the material, and it is hard to think of something that Sekhar could do differently to make it more accessible because it seems clear that he is already trying. Maybe more time could be spent on starting with motivating problems with relatable examples? Sekhar already tries to make things more interactive by asking the class some questions but gets little response, but maybe he could try some more direct in-class activities where we have to discuss something amongst ourselves in small groups at the start of class to get some intuition for examples?

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I highly recommend this course for students who want to gain foundational knowledge in convex optimization.

Take this course! No matter how much optimization you thought you knew, you will learn so much more! Be warned though, that this is foremost a proof-based math course, not a computer science course nor applied S&DS course.
Yes. It is an interesting class to get an overview of popular optimization algorithms and techniques.

Depending on what the student hopes to gain from the class. Yes if they only want an overview of optimization techniques to get some sense about how the field is like. No if they had little previous exposure to the field but also want to gain a deep understanding on the topics.
This is a great course to really learn about convex optimization, so I definitely recommend it to any student interested in the subject.
Yes, if you want to learn about basic optimization techniques nowadays.
Yes. This is a good course to take and important stuff to know. Take it.
Professor Sekhar explains concepts and theorems explicitly. Moreover, optimization is intersting. If you plan to do research on this area, you can take the course.
Yes! If you have a solid math background and are interested in learning more about optimization techniques and building your toolset for problems involving optimization, take this class!
Yes
Yes, very good lectures that provide intuiton

Yes.
It is amazing that the course materials are hard but Sekhar taught it really well and explained the hard concepts and algorithms really clear (though the pace is really fast)
Yes.
Yes! Its the course can influence your view about optimization and machine learning

I would, but only if you have strong interest in this subject material and/or if you think it will be useful to your research (I think Sekhar would say the same).  Since it can get pretty technical I don't think you will have a good time if you don't have a preexisting interest.

Sekhar does not shy away from going in-depth over each topic covered in the course. Those who have taken an optimization course but want to develop a level of understanding that allows one to do excellent research in the said field should take this course.
